subject: Re: [junit] JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: ... Then don t say things like JUnit considered problematic . I would prefer that you know what you re writing about before you draw such a strong conclusion.
messageBody:
>So said javainsel on 4/1/2003 --------------------
>Sorry, I know very little about both of them until now.

Then don't say things like "JUnit considered problematic". I would prefer that you know what you're writing about before you draw such a strong conclusion.

>But it seems to me that I don't need necessarily JUnit test cases or
>suites if I use the new assert statement in the code I write.

True.

>Of course it is better to have JUnit tests, but it has many side
>effects in my eyes. Using assert statements would be a compromise.

Writing Programmer Tests (forget JUnit for now) has many positive side effects, true. No need to compromise.

>I think I could use assert statements at the beginning of a method
>and at the end, checking preconditions and postconditions.

Certainly you may.

>By marking them somehow as preconditions and postconditions it should
>theoretically be possible to automate generation of JUnit
>tests/suites, including test data. The test data can be created
>automatically by a tool which obeys the preconditions for that
>purpose.

JTest does this. Most Test-Driven programmers I have spoken with do not find it valuable, including me. There must be a reason we agree that generating this kinds of boundary tests are not valuable compared to the kinds of tests we prefer to write.

(Hint: writing tests is a design activity.)

>It seems that with JUnit I can only test methods which return a
>value.

So utterly false I can't overstate the fact.

>Using JUnit will change the code one would normally create:
>Because of JUnit you need to overwrite equals(), toString() and are
>not allowed to use void return type if you want to test that method.

Even more false than the previous statement.

>Using the assert statement instead I can also test classes which
>return no value.

We do this with JUnit every day.

>Besides all this problems whis JUnit is another one: Successful
>JUnits tests are no guarantee that there are no bugs in the code I
>read. This has to do with data chains. But I didn't understand this.

You are now being ridiculous. No testing ever proves anything; therefore we should all go home and drink tea. This absurd argument is the last vestige of the desperate.

At this point I must ask you to go away, read several books on testing, then come back and stop talking nonsense.

Thanks.


J. B. Rainsberger,
